questions.neutral: Timing's good - not too busy, huh?

hobby.message: You still tuning those antique typewriters?
Political literature still whispering to you?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: Yeah, quiet is rare lately. Suits me, honestly.
I shoot street photos on film. Just snapshots, nothing official.
Had to lay low after last week—too many eyes, you know.
These days, every frame feels risky.
Not bad to have space to think for once.
I shoot analog photos—35mm film, old stuff.
Been harder lately, since the Tribunal mess.
Snapping protest chalk before it’s gone, but compliance doesn’t like that.
Last roll almost got me flagged.
Glad it’s slow. Makes my hobby easier—street photography, real film.
Streets changed after that analog broadcast. Suddenly more patrols, fewer smiles.
Had to hide my camera quick two days ago, near the old square.
The Tribunal crackdown means I print in secret now.
Caught some returnees on film, even if I can’t show anyone.
Keeps me sharp, staying invisible.
Good timing. Gave me space to develop film in peace last week.
I shoot analog—35mm, always on the street. Smuggled film is gold to me.
Since the Tribunal ended, every outing is a gamble.
Almost got spotted snapping a reunion between returnees.
Those moments—the city’s real pulse—won’t show up in state stories.
I keep the negatives hidden, develop at night now.
Used to be a thrill, now it’s pure survival.
Yeah, I check the crowd now, even here. Paranoid, maybe. Necessary.
I’m obsessed with analog street photography—everything they try to erase, I shoot it.
After the Citizen Tribunal shutdown, every chalk slogan or lost face is a risk and a story.
My father was BCI, you know. He’d spin official lines, I’d sneak shots out the window.
Spent three hours in a stairwell last week, waiting for patrols to pass.
I know I’m flagged—score’s in the gutter. Doesn’t stop me documenting the truth.
Sometimes I leak photos, but mostly it’s about having proof someone saw.
Film’s rare, but so is honesty here. I won’t give that up.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Still at it when I can.
Film's hard to get, streets aren't safe now.
Last week, compliance was everywhere after that Tribunal mess.
No shots worth risking my BCI over lately.
Not much more to say.
Still chasing, but more looking over my shoulder now.
Got stopped twice since the blackout. They're checking cameras.
Crowds feel skittish since the Tribunal broadcasts got yanked.
Even raw shots risk getting flagged now.
Almost got a reel confiscated Saturday.
Just pushing my luck, I guess.
Always chasing. Analog’s stubborn, like memory.
Saturday I shot new chalk messages before they were scrubbed.
Since the Tribunal blackout, even empty walls feel loud.
Compliance patrols watched me reload film. Made it tense.
People look away from the lens now, not at it.
That sense of urgency... it hangs on every frame lately.
Truth’s harder to find, but more necessary.
Chasing ghosts is right. Feels almost illegal, just pausing time lately.
Was at West Gate after the Tribunal clips vanished—chalk messages everywhere.
Every click could get you flagged; patrols look twice at cameras now.
I had to hide fresh film under street flyers last week.
It feels like we're documenting a city erasing itself in real time.
Shooting faces is risky—everyone's wary after that analog broadcast leak.
But the best shots: hands writing, eyes searching, nothing digital can fake.
Can't help it—saving the fragments matters more now.
Still out there, even if it feels like sabotage sometimes.
Grew up watching my BCI-officer mother destroy negatives. Now I salvage them.
These days, after Tribunal and blackout—film's gold, every frame urgent.
Saturday I caught the chalk writers; felt illegal just focusing the lens.
Used to worry about losing prints; now it’s losing the story behind them.
Had a patrol ask for my shot list; lied and said it’s all empty street.
The real scenes are what the Council wants erased: reunions, protests, ghosts returning.
I stash canisters under bar stools, between newsprint—analog’s the only way left.
Sometimes I think I’m cataloguing the city's memory, before the system scrubs us all.
